results.title: Cuphead: Inspiration from the Inkwell
results.brief_description: The charming and cheeky animated characters of Studio MDHR’s Cuphead videogame spring into action in this contemporary incarnation of the popular 19th century invention, the zoetrope.

constellations_primary.name: Timeless early animation
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation traces the inspirations and evolution of the Cuphead animation technique and franchise back to the early 20th century and beyond.

results.description:
The charming and cheeky animated characters of Studio MDHR’s Cuphead videogame spring into action in this contemporary incarnation of the popular 19th-century invention, the zoetrope. Designed specifically for ACMI by Studio MDHR, this zoetrope spins and uses strobe lighting to create the illusion of 90 individual characters magically coming to life. Watch as Cuphead, Mugman, Ms Chalice, King Dice and the Devil all animate before your eyes in a series of poses representing the way Cuphead mixes classic animation with modern digital gaming.

Heavily inspired by the classic cartoons of the 1930s – particularly Fleischer Studios and Walt Disney – Studio MDHR used hand-drawn cel animation, watercolour backgrounds and original jazz recordings to create the world of Cuphead – one of the most successful run-and-gun videogames in recent memory.
description_for_label:
The charming and cheeky animated characters of Studio MDHR’s Cuphead videogame spring into action in this contemporary incarnation of the popular 19th-century invention, the zoetrope. Designed specifically for ACMI by Studio MDHR, this zoetrope spins and uses strobe lighting to create the illusion of 90 individual characters magically coming to life. Watch as Cuphead, Mugman, Ms Chalice, King Dice and the Devil all animate before your eyes in a series of poses representing the way Cuphead mixes classic animation with modern digital gaming.

Heavily inspired by the classic cartoons of the 1930s – particularly Fleischer Studios and Walt Disney – Studio MDHR used hand-drawn cel animation, watercolour backgrounds and original jazz recordings to create the world of Cuphead – one of the most successful run-and-gun videogames in recent memory.

results.title: Cuphead
results.brief_description: Cuphead is a classic run and gun action game inspired by cartoons of the 1930s, with the visuals and audio painstakingly created with the same techniques of the era like traditional cel animation, watercolor backgrounds, and original jazz recordings.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: MoCaps and rotos
constellations_other.description: Though VFX continues to push boundaries and brings fantastical worlds and creatures to life, there's still a place for classic animation techniques.

results.title: Cup final [1961]
results.brief_description: Sporting documentary on the 1961 FA Cup final of Tottenham Hotspurs versus Leicester City at Wembley Stadium. Historical in the sense that Spurs won 2-0 and became the first team in the history of English football to win both the League and Cup double.
results.description: Sporting documentary on the 1961 FA Cup final of Tottenham Hotspurs versus Leicester City at Wembley Stadium. Historical in the sense that Spurs won 2-0 and became the first team in the history of English football to win both the League and Cup double.

results.title: Cunnamulla (A)
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Dennis O'Rourke, Camerawork and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: The small outback town of Cunnamulla is situated in rural Queensland, 800 kilometres west of Brisbane. As one of the characters in this documentary says, “Cunnamulla is a town at the end of the railroad”, a once prosperous sheep farming territory that now has high levels of unemployment and petty crime. O’Rourke allows the people of the town to speak for themselves. The picture they paint is bleak; a town divided along racial and age lines, where whites and Aborigines are mutually suspicious of each other, where parents and grandparents can no longer understand the choices their children are making when it comes to sex, drugs and work. Filmed over the approaching Christmas period, “Cunnamulla” has its fair share of eccentric and stoic human beings, but the overriding impression is that the rapid pace of globalisation is exacerbating conflict and leading to the death of the very town itself. Whether it is in the doleful expression of a young man about to enter prison, or in the exasperated eyes of a father talking about his heavy metal obsessed son, O’Rourke’s film creates a vivid, powerful and disturbing portrait of outback Australia.

results.title: Cummington story
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of War Information. Overseas Operations Branch
results.brief_description: The story of the arrival in Cummington, USA, of a group of refugees from Europe and the manner in which they were accepted by the community. They are greeted by the minister of the local church, who has assumed the responsibility for their adjustment to a strange country, and has found a place for them to live. Then began the process of gradually breaking down the barriers between the new arrivals and the townspeople. Strangeness falls away, the minister implies, when people live and work and meet together. The story of this exercise in human relations is told with sympathy, understanding, and humour.

results.title: Cumberland story
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit, Alexander Shaw and Humphrey Jennings
results.brief_description: A dramatised documentary, made for the Ministry of Fuel and Power, aiming to reassure miners about the proposed nationalisation of the coal fields. Revolves around the dramatic tale of a disaster which involved the loss of many lives almost 100 years earlier. The seam located under the sea floor is opened up again for working, and with modern equipment and safety devices, there is little likelihood of a repetition of the old tragedy. Many of the roles are performed by the actual workers, Nimmo is played by a mining engineer and Stephenson is one of the mine leaders. Cinematography, Chick Fowle. Music, Arthur Benjamin performed by the Philharmonic Orchestra. Made in collaboration with the United Steel Companies and the National Union of Mine-Workers.

results.title: Cultures of mothering
results.creator_credit: Monash University and Robert de Young
results.brief_description: Mothering is an issue that demands attention, but is often only brought in the public arena on the rather commercialised Mother’s Day. Mothering is a significant part of life that is not often considered as a separate issue for women. This program addresses mothering in Australian society and raises the level of debate about issues relating to mothering. Mothering is looked at over generations as well as its changing identity in contemporary society today. Mothering across cultures, the status of mothering, sexuality and mothering, as well as stereotypes are explored within this program, giving voice to a number of women who share their experiences of mothering. Produced by the Monash University Centre for Women’s Studies.

results.title: Cultured pearls
results.brief_description: The complete process of pearl culture. Women divers take oysters from the seabed, which are injected with tissue and kernels, and placed in wire baskets to mature in warm sea water in bays and inlets. A careful watch is kept on the temperature and conditions of the sea, and the oysters are moved in the water as necessary. The shells are cleaned once a year, until harvesting, when the pearls are removed, graded, inspected and made up for dealers.

results.title: Culture, time & place
results.creator_credit: DLGHS, GPN, George A. Colburn and Darrel Schwandt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Language, schooling and the interactions of everyday life are vehicles of acculturation that communicate values, beliefs, attitudes and expectations to children. Observing a traditional Japanese religious festival, we explore the myth and ritual which help children see their relationship to time, place and values.
